text: Causes of catastrophic sediment failures of the Amazon Fan
Mark Maslina,, Claudia Vilelab, Naja Mikkelsenc, Pieter Grootesd

aEnvironmental Change Research Centre, Department of Geography, University College London, 26 Bedford Way, London WC1H OAP, UK
bDepartamento de Geologia/IGEO/CCMN, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Ilha do Funda˜o-21949-900 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brasil
cGeological Survey of Denmark and Greenland, Qslen Voldgade 10, 1350, Copenhagen, Denmark
dLeibniz Labor fur Altersbestimmung und Isotopenforschung, Max-Eyth-Str. 11-13, Universita¨t Kiel, D-24118 Kiel, Germany

The general Pleistocene architecture of the Amazon Fan has been reconstructed using sediment recovered by Ocean Drilling
Program Leg 155. Huge regional mass-transport deposits (MTDs) make up a signiﬁcant component of the Amazon Fan. These
deposits each cover an area over 15,000 km2 (approximately the size of Jamaica), reach a maximum thickness of 200 m, and consist
of 5000 Gt of sediment. Benthic foraminiferal fauna analysis and sedimentology indicate that the MTDs originated on the
continental slope, which is at least 200 km laterally and 1500 m above their present position. Each mass-failure event was formed by
the catastrophic failure of the continental slope and has been dated and correlated with climate-induced changes in sea level. Studies
of the benthic foraminiferal assemblages in the Amazon Fan has been essential to our reconstruction of the origin and cause of these
failures. The MTDs contain rare shelf (Quinqueloculina cf. stalkeri, Brizalina aenariensis, Q. lamarckiana, and Pseudononion
atlanticum) and dominant upper-middle bathyal species (cassidulinids and buliminids). We conclude that the MTD originated
between 200 and 600 m water depth, approximately the same zone in which gas hydrates occur. We suggest that the glacial MTDs
referred to as Deep Eastern MTD (35–37 ka) and Unit R MTD (41–45 ka) correlate with rapid drops in sea level which destabilized
continental slope gas-hydrate reservoirs causing catastrophic slope failure. An alternative explanation is required for the deglacial
MTDs referred to as Western and Eastern Debris Flows (13–14 ka) which occurred as sea level rose rapidly during the Bølling-
Allerød period. We suggest that the deglaciation of the Andes and the consequent enhanced sediment supply coupled with a shift of
the depo-centre to the continental shelf, caused over-burdening and thus slope failure. Evidence for a 2% negative d13C shift in both
planktonic foraminifera and organic matter coeval with these failures suggest that whatever the cause, there was a large release of
methane hydrate associated with each failure.
r 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Deep-sea fans are a major depository for terrestrial
sediment (e.g., Flood and Piper, 1997). The Amazon Fan is
one of the world’s largest fans, which started to develop in
the early Miocene due to the Andean uplift (e.g., Damuth
and Kumar, 1975; Curry et al., 1995; Hoorn et al., 1995).
Mass-transport deposits (MTDs) cover extensive areas of

Corresponding author. Tel.: +44 20 7679 7556;
fax: +44 20 7679 7565.
E-mail addresses: mmaslin@geography.ucl.ac.uk (M. Maslin),
vilela@geologia.ufrj.br (C. Vilela), nm@geus.dk (N. Mikkelsen),
pgrootes@kibniz.uni-kiel.de (P. Grootes).

0277-3791/$ - see front matter r 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
doi:10.1016/j.quascirev.2005.01.016

the continental margins and are considered one of the
major components of deep-sea fans (Piper et al., 1997a).
The study of MTDs contributes to the knowledge of
glacial-interglacial cycles, depositional processes, sediment
dynamics of fans and sequence stratigraphy. Mass-failure
sediments occur in the deep ocean due to gravity processes
causing slumps, slides and turbidity currents, which
originate at much shallower depths (Shanmugam et al.,
1994). The Amazon Fan MTDs are huge, covering an area
over 15,000km2. They are thought to be slumps and/or
slides because the sediments contain less ﬂuid or water than
turbidites and are deposited as blocks or randomly without
particle selection (Flood et al., 1995; Normark et al., 1997;
Piper et al., 1997a; Maslin et al., 1998).

The Amazon Fan has a coherent structure caused by
the switching on and off of the deposition of sediment
from the continent. During the Holocene and previous
interglacial periods, the surface-water circulation and
the expanse of the continental shelf trapped the Amazon
River outﬂow so that terrigenous sediment was depos-
ited predominantly on the inner continental shelf
(Gibbs, 1967; Milliman et al., 1975). The Amazon Fan
was thus inactive and only pelagic sediments accumu-
lated during such interglacial periods (Damuth, 1977;
Damuth et al., 1988; Flood et al., 1995; Flood and Piper,
1997). Sedimentation rates of Holocene and previous
interglacial Amazon Fan sediments reﬂect this and are
approximately 5–10 cm/kyrs (Mikkelsen et al., 1997).
During glacial periods the lower sea level allowed the
Amazon River sediment to bypass the continental shelf
and feed directly into the Amazon Canyon and hence
into
the
Amazon
Fan
complex
(Fig.
1).
Glacial
sedimentation rates ranged from 1 m/ka to more than
50 m/ka, a 20–1000 fold increase compared with the
Holocene sedimentation rates (Mikkelsen et al., 1997;
Piper et al., 1997b; Rimington, 1999). The coherent
structure of the Amazon Fan has allowed us to date and
reconstruct the possible causation of the MTDs.

2. Sedimentary components recovered from the Amazon
Fan

The Amazon Fan complex is composed of several
sedimentological units that have been deﬁned by careful
analysis of seismic and sedimentological data (Flood et
al., 1995; Flood and Piper, 1997; Normark et al., 1997;
Piper et al., 1997a,b). The key components of the
Amazon Fan are (1) a thin Holocene ooze that caps the
entire fan area and includes at its base a time-
transgressive iron-rich crust, (2) glacial channel-levee
deposits, (3) mass-transport deposits (MTDs) and (4)
relatively
thin
calcium
carbonate
rich
interglacial
deposits found beneath the MTDs.
ODP Leg 155 penetrated MTDs at 8 sites (Fig. 1A)
and recovered sediment from the entire unit of the
MTDs and underlying sediment at 7 of these sites (Fig.
1B). The four Late Pleistocene MTDs drilled each cover
an area of approximately 200 km down-slope and
100 km wide and are about 100–200 m thick, see Figs.
1 and 2 (Manley and Flood, 1988; Pirmez and Flood,
1995; Flood and Piper, 1997; Piper et al., 1997a,b;
Maslin and Mikkelsen, 1998). Each deposit is half the
size of the biggest Hawaiian slide (Moore et al., 1994),
ﬁve times larger than the Mediterranean ‘‘megaturbi-
dite’’ recorded by Rothwell et al. (1998), and of a size
comparable to that of the Nordic Seas Storegga (Bugge
et al., 1987) and North Sea (King et al., 1996) slides.
Two major deep MTDs were cored during Leg 155
(Figs. 1 and 2). The ﬁrst, the ‘‘Unit R Debris Flow’’

B: Relative stratigraphic positions of mass transport deposits and
interglacial deposits recovered from late Quaternary Amazon Fan
complex. Interglacial sediment deposits, excluding pervasive Holocene
covering, are present in seven of the sites and are characterized by
fairly high content of carbonate (almost 40%). Levee muds are found
between the deep mass transport deposit Unit R and the underlying
interglacial deposit. In contrast, interglacial sediments were found
directly below the Deep Eastern MTD (Bottom MTD).

(Manley and Flood, 1988), underlies the Upper Levee
Complex which was formed during the Last Glacial, and
was recovered at Sites 935, 936 and 944 (Fig. 2). Unit R
was found to have levee muds directly below the contact
surface. At Sites 936 and 944 an addition sand unit
approximately 40 m thick was recovered below the levee
muds. Below this sandy unit and directly below the levee
muds at Site 935, are interglacial carbonate-rich units.
The second MTD on the eastern part of the Amazon
Fan, here termed the Deep Eastern MTD (also referred
to as the Bottom MTD, Piper et al., 1997a), overlies the
crest of the Bottom Levee Complex and was cored at
Sites 931 and 933 (Figs. 1 and 2). This ancient MTD was
found to have interglacial sediments directly below the
contact surface. The interglacial sediment units are
present in 7 of the sites and are characterized by a fairly
high content of carbonate (up to almost 40%) and by the
presence of calcareous nannofossils and foraminifera.
There are also two near-surface MTDs, termed the
Eastern and Western ‘‘Debris Flow’’ by Damuth et al.
(1988), see Figs. 1 and 2. Only the Western Debris Flow
was cored at Site 941 and the base was recovered at
130 mbsf, conﬁrming the depth estimated from seismics
(Flood et al., 1995). A full description of all the units
recovered by ODP Leg 155 can be found in Flood et al.
(1995).

Calcareous nannofossils: The nannofossil assemblages
were described directly from smear slides prepared from
unprocessed sediment. The slides were prepared using
standard methods (Maslin and Mikkelsen, 1997, 1998;

Mikkelsen et al., 1997). The zonal scheme of Bukry
(1973, 1978), Okada and Bukry (1980), Pujos and
Giraudeau (1993) and Rafﬁet al. (1993), includes only
two datums for the time period covered by the sequences
drilled, the ﬁrst occurrence of Emiliania huxleyi at
260 ka and the onset of the E. huxleyi acme at
approximately 85 ka (Fig. 3). The sediments recovered
during
Leg
155
are
all
younger
than
460 ka
as
Pseudoemiliania lacunosa was not observed.
Benthic foraminifera: In Holes 933A, and 936A,
subsamples were analysed every 10 m throughout the
MTDs. In Hole 941A two samples were analysed. All
samples were washed and sieved at 63 mm, and then oven
dried at 60 1C. All specimens were counted and classiﬁed
(Table 1), according to Loeblich and Tappan (1988),
Ellis
and
Messina
catalogue
(1940),
and
speciﬁc
systematic classiﬁcation of taxonomy by Vilela (1998)
copies of which are available on request from the second
author. Benthic foraminiferal species were compared
with assemblages from the Amazon continental shelf
and upper-middle slope. The shelf assemblages are
known in detail from previous work on the AmasSeds
Project (A Multidisciplinary Amazon Shelf Sediment
Study, e.g., Nittrouer et al., 1991; Vilela, 1993, 1995)
and the slope assemblages are known from the REMAC
Project—Projeto de Reconhecimento Global da Mar-
gem Continental Brasileira (Santos, 1972; Vilela, 1998)
the results of which are summarized in Fig. 4. Benthic
foraminiferal assemblages of both near-surface and the
Last Glacial Maximum samples at Site 933 and 936
assisted the comparative study (Vilela and Maslin, 1997;
Vilela, 1998).
Stable isotopes: The oxygen and carbon isotopes of
the benthic and planktonic foraminiferal tests were

measured at Sites 932, 933 and 936. After freeze-drying
and wet sieving, the samples were dry sieved at intervals
between 250 and 400 mm, and the tests were picked. Two
benthic species were selected for analysis: Cibicides
wuellerstorﬁand Uvigerina sp.; as well as six planktonic
species: Globigerinoides sacculifer, G. ruber, G. trilobus,
Neogloboquadrina
dutertrei,
P.
obliquiloculata
and
Globorotalia truncatulinoides (Vilela and Maslin, 1997).
The isotope analyses were performed using a Finnigan
MAT 251 mass spectrometer, at the Leibniz Labora-
tory, Kiel (Vilela and Maslin, 1997). Stable oxygen
isotope records were used to conﬁrming stratigraphy
when there were clear continuous sequences above the
MTD (Flood et al., 1995), for example Sites 933 and 941
(Maslin et al., 1997; Showers et al., 1997). Carbon
isotope records were used to identify periods when
isotopically light carbon was present in the surface
waters.
Paleomagnetism: Conventional magnetic stratigraphy
of the Leg 155 Amazon Fan sediments was not possible
because of the relatively young ages of the sediments
recovered, i.e., less than 460 ka (Mikkelsen et al., 1997).
It was possible to take advantage of the very high
sedimentation rates to use several other less-utilized
magnetostratigraphic techniques (Cisowski and Hall,
1997). These include identiﬁcation of short periods of
anomalous geomagnetic polarity (i.e., events and excur-
sions) in the archive-half magnetic remanence record
and the recognition of distinctive patterns in the
magnetic remanence intensity (or geomagnetic paleoin-
tensity) which seem to correlate with well dated marine
records from the North and South Atlantic as well as the
Mediterranean (Tric et al., 1992; Stoner et al., 2002).
Using
the
magnetic
remanence
intensity
the
two
excursions observed were identiﬁed as the younger Lake
Mungo and Laschamp excursions. Cisowski and Hall

(1997) have successfully identiﬁed 12 intensity features
in the Amazon Fan sediments which correlate with the
South Atlantic Paleointensity Stack (SAPIS) produced
by Stoner et al. (2002) which can be correlated in the
Amazon Fan sediments. These were used as the basis of
the age models of Sites 931, 933, 935 and 936 (see
Fig. 3).
Accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) radiocarbon
dating: Monospeciﬁc foraminifera samples containing
about 1 mg of carbon were cleaned with 15% H2O2 in an
ultrasonic bath to remove adhering dust and detrital
carbonate as well as organic surface coating. The CO2
was liberated from each sample with 100% phosphoric
acid at 90 1C. The sample CO2 was reduced with H2 over
2 mg of Fe powder which acts as a catalyst. The resulting
carbon/iron mixture was pressed into a pellet in the
target holder. The 14C concentration of the samples was
measured with the 3-MV HVEE Tandetron AMS-
system of the Leibniz Laboratory by comparing the
simultaneously collected 14C, 13C, and 12C beams of
each sample with those of Oxalic Acid standard CO2
and pre-Eemian foraminifera (Nadeau et al., 1997,
1998). Conventional 14C ages were calculated with a
d13C correction for isotopic fractionation based on the
13C/12C ratio measured by our AMS-system simulta-
neously with the 14C/12C ratio. See Figs. 3 and 5 for
AMS radiocarbon dating results on Sites 933, 936 and
941 converted to calendar years using Hughen et al.
(2004).

The reconstruction of the stratigraphy and overall
structure of the Amazon Fan (Figs. 1–3) is based on
calcareous nannofossils and planktonic foraminifera

Fig. 5. Comparison of the lithological units recovered at Hole 941B
and the radiocarbon dates obtained. Note that hole 941B was used as
941A Unit I contains a foraminifera-rich turbidite at the boundary
between Units I and II (Flood et al., 1995).

biostratigraphy (Mikkelsen et al., 1997), paleomagnet-
ism (Flood et al., 1995; Cisowski and Hall, 1997, dated
using SAPIS Stoner et al., 2002), stable isotope records
(Maslin et al., 1997; Showers et al., 1997; Vilela and
Maslin, 1997), radiocarbon dating (Maslin et al., 1998
and this study), amino acid racemization (Wehmiller
and Hall, 1997), and seismic interpretations (Flood et
al., 1995; Pirmez and Flood, 1995; Piper et al., 1997a,b).
We have dated the occurrence of MTDs features within
the Amazon Fan complex using biostratigraphy, seismic
stratigraphy, radiocarbon dating, magneto stratigraphy
and sedimentation-rate constraints (Fig. 3). The strati-
graphic synthesis suggests the Deep Eastern MTD
occurred between 35 and 37 calendar ka. The range of
values is due to the assumed sedimentation rate of the
hemipelagic/levee muds between the last datable horizon

and the top of the MTD. The interpretation of the
different facies on top of the MTD at 931 (sands and
muds) and 933 (levee muds) suggests that the older date
of 37 ka may be the more accurate. The stratigraphy
synthesis suggest the ‘‘deep western’’ Unit R MTD was
deposited between 41 and 45 calendar ka. If it is
assumed that the sand unit on top of the Unit R MTD
was deposited during an avulsion event then the
sedimentation rate would have been extremely high
making the younger date of 41 ka more like age of the
MTD. The nannofossil assemblages in the deep inter-
glacial layers (Maslin and Mikkelsen, 1998) indicates
that the interglacial unit below the Deep Eastern MTD
(Bottom MTD) cannot be older than that beneath the
Unit R MTD.
Both the Eastern and Western near-surface debris
ﬂows are capped by Holocene sediments. However, only
the Western Debris Flow was drilled during Leg 155 at
Site 941. The sediment recovered from Site 941 has been
divided in to three main sedimentological units (Fig. 5).
Unit I contains foraminifera clay which is typical of all
Holocene sediments overlying the Amazon Fan. Unit II
contains clay with extremely rare foraminifera suggest-
ing that it was deposited very rapidly. Unit III is the
Western Debris Flow MTD and is composed of large
blocks and clasts in a clay matrix. AMS radiocarbon
dates have been measured on the base of Unit I and
within Unit III. No dates were possible for Unit II as the
foraminifera abundance was so low. The basal date for
Unit I is 10,740780 14C years, 13,000 calendar years
(KIA 19022). Unit II is interpreted to be either an
instantaneous or very rapidly deposited clay. The
evidence for this is the sparcity of pelagic material, for
example the very low organic matter content (Flood et
al., 1995) and the very low abundance of foraminifera
(Flood et al., 1995 and this study). We conclude that the
Western Debris Flow was deposited shortly before
13 ka. This is consistent with the radiocarbon dating
and oxygen isotope correlation of Leg 155 sediments
and nearby piston cores (Piper et al., 1997b; Showers et
al., 1997). Radiocarbon dates within the MTD show
that the ﬁrst 14 m is composed mainly of glacial aged
sediment. There is clear re-working or mixing of blocks
within the MTD as shown by the date reversal between
7 mbsf (20,8707120 14C years, KIA 19023) and 21 mbsf
(18,2707100 14C years, KIA 19024). Seismic interpreta-
tions suggest the Western and Eastern Debris Flows are
coeval (Flood et al., 1995; Piper et al., 1997b) implying
that the Eastern Debris Flow also occurred sometime
just before 13 ka.
5. Origin of the sediment within the MTDs

Low abundance and diversity of benthic foraminifera
is characteristic of all the MTD sediments. The tests are

frequently small, abraded, and brown, characteristics of
sediment transport and reworking. The occurrence of
the most abundant species is shown in Figs. 4 and 6 and
Table 1. The buliminids, e.g., Bulimina gibba, B.
aculeata, B. marginata, and B. costata, are dominant
in all the MTD samples. Cassidulina laevigata, Globo-
cassidulina subglobosa, Stainforthia complanata, Brizali-
na aenariensis, Pseudononion atlanticum, Q. lamarckiana
and Uvigerina peregrina were found in the Deep Eastern
MTD, Unit R MTD and Western Debris Flow; while
Quinqueloculina cf. stalkeri was only found in the Deep
Eastern MTD and Western Debris Flow.
Buliminids, cassidulinids, and uvigerinids characterize
bathyal environments (Phleger, 1960; Murray, 1973;
Pﬂum and Frerichs, 1976; Miller and Lohmann, 1982;
Sen Gupta and Strickert, 1982; Streeter and Lavery,
1982; Culver, 1988; Murray, 1991; Lagoe et al., 1994).
This has been conﬁrmed for the Brasilian margin as C.
laevigata, G. subglobosa, and species of Bulimina are
commonly encountered in sediments of the Amazon
upper and middle slope (e.g., Vilela, 1995, 1998). U.
peregrina are also found in the Amazon slope and in the
MTD sediments (Vilela and Maslin, 1997; Vilela, 1998).
In addition characteristic Amazon shelf species, such as
Quinqueloculina
cf.
stalkeri, P.
atlanticum
and
Q.
lamarckiana were found in all the MTDs. Fig. 4 shows
the

and

indicator species. Those species are dominant in the
shelf and slope, except for Quinqueloculina cf. stalkeri.
In the Deep Eastern MTD, shelf species abundances
increase in the middle of the core, and then decrease
down the core, with a corresponding increase of bathyal
species. At the bottom of the unit, both shelf and slope
species disappeared (Fig. 6). In the Unit R MTD, species
abundances are signiﬁcant only at the top of Unit R,
with occurrences of both shelf and slope species.
Characteristic species from the abyssal depth, such as,
Laticarinina pauperata and Bathysiphon spp., and lower-
bathyal to abyssal such as C. wuellerstorﬁ, were found in
both Holocene pelagic and in situ Late Pleistocene
hemipelagic sediments collected at Sites across the
Amazon Fan (Vilela and Maslin, 1997). However, these
species were not present in the MTDs. We suggest that
the MTDs originated in the upper-middle bathyal
environments, with another possible secondary source
area on the shelf (Vilela and Maslin, 1997; Vilela, 1998).
We speculate that the shelf species could have been
transported into the slope and then carried into the Fan
via the catastrophic failure and the formation of the
MTDs. Another interesting point to consider is that
during the Last Glacial sea level was about 100 m lower,
and the region comprising the present shelf was exposed.
Consequently, increased sub-aerial weathering may have
contributed more shelf species to the slope.

An intriguing question concerning the Amazon Fan
MTDs is what caused these instantaneous massive
sediment failures. Although there have been extensive
investigations into the causes of large debris ﬂows from
around the world (e.g., Nisbet and Piper, 1998) exact
causes
remain
unknown. Suggested causes include
earthquakes (Kastens, 1984; Rothwell et al., 1998), high
sedimentation rates due to proximity to ﬂuvial inputs
(Prior and Suhayda, 1979), sea-level ﬂuctuations (Wea-
ver and Kuijpers, 1983; Roberts and Cramp, 1997),
progressive failure (Moore, 1961), creep (Moore et al.,
1994), and gas-hydrate destabilization (Kayen and Lee,
1991; Haq, 1995; Maslin et al., 1998; Rothwell et al.,
1998; Paull and Dillon, 2001; Kennett et al., 2003).
Submarine earthquakes are thought to unlikely in this
area as the seismic potential of the lower Amazon Basin
is extremely low (Giardini, 1999). We have, however,
considered all these theories along with evidence from
drilling of the Amazon Fan to infer which one is the
most applicable to the Amazon MTDs.
The benthic foraminifera microfaunal evidence, de-
tailed above suggests the sediment within the MTDs
must have originated at water depths of between 200
and 600 m i.e., on the upper continental slope. The
MTDs must have travelled laterally more than 200 km
and bathymetrically down at least 1500 m to have
reached their current locations. This is supported by
the discrete clasts found in the MTDs which contain
either Pliocene or Miocene nannofossil assemblages
which can have only originated from the exposed
Pliocene and Miocene sections on the Brasilian upper
continental slope. The strong consistent internal struc-
ture of the MTDs from both sedimentological and
biostratigraphic
evidence
(Flood
and
Piper,
1997;
Mikkelsen et al., 1997; Normark et al., 1997; Vilela
and Maslin, 1997) and relatively low angle of the slope
traversed (o11) indicate that these are slump deposits.
Catastrophic slump events are usually caused by either
rapid dissociation of gas hydrates (Kayen and Lee, 1991;
Haq, 1993, 1995, 1998; Rothwell et al., 1998; Dillon et
al., 2001) or by over-burdening of the sediment column
(Weaver and Kuijpers, 1983; Roberts and Cramp, 1997;
Nisbet and Piper, 1998).

The
initiation
of
the
two
deep
glacial
MTDs
corresponds to periods of rapidly falling sea level
between 35 and 37 ka and between 41 and 45 ka (e.g.,
Shackleton, 1987; Flood et al., 1995; Chappell et al.,
1996; McGuire et al., 1997; Chappell, 2002), see Fig. 7.
Two causes have been suggested: in situ slumping and
gas hydrate release due to sea level lowering. In situ
slumping of the channel-levee deposits was suggested by

(1989) and Shackleton (1987) are compared to the occurrence of mass

ODP Sites 933, 941, 942 and 944, which indicates the key switch
occurring between 13 and 13.5 calendar ka (Maslin et al., 2000). (c)
Shows the period of inundation of the Amazon River lower complex
between 14 and 6 ka, which includes ﬂooded valleys and the
development of large lakes (Irion et al., 1995).

Piper et al. (1997a) based on seismic data and the
presence of carbonate-rich interglacial deposits at the
base of the units. These sediments would be deformed
and slumped in situ. However, there is the evidence for

distinct blocks or subunits in the MTDs, which occur
both in depth and lateral domain, made evident by
lithology and foraminiferal contents (Piper et al.,
1997a,b; Vilela and Maslin, 1997; Maslin et al., 1998).
By considering the original climatic conditions under
which the sediment in the MTDs were formed, inferred
from their planktonic foraminiferal assemblages (Vilela
and Maslin, 1997), suggests that these blocks have
different sources of material. In the Deep Eastern MTD
there are three distinct blocks positioned one on top of
another. In the Unit R the same unit has different blocks
at different sites across the Fan (Vilela and Maslin,
1997).
The
benthic
foraminiferal
assemblage
data
indicate a more distal source. Moreover, Maslin and
Mikkelsen (1997) suggested that the structurally weaker
carbonate-rich interglacial deposits may have acted as
slip-planes for the MTDs. In such a case the inclusion of
interglacial material in the base of the MTDs would be
expected.
We, therefore, suggest gas hydrate release as the most
likely cause. The sea-level drops which correlate with the
MTDs are indeed very rapid. McGuire et al. (1997)
estimated rates between 15 and 25 m/ka (Fig. 7), which
would be sufﬁcient to reduced the hydrostatic pressure
enough to destablize gas-hydrate reservoirs on the
continental slope (e.g., Haq, 1993, 1995; Kvenvolden,
1993; Kennett et al., 2003). We speculate that it was the
rapidity of the release of pressure below a critical sea
level that caused the dissociation of clathrate and thus
mass failure of the North Brazilian continental slope.
The origin of the MTDs at water depths of between 200
and 600 m supports this hypothesis as this is where the
most sensitive gas-hydrate reservoir is located. Acoustic
data of the Amazon Fan and the Brazilian continental
slope indicates the presence of gas hydrates through
bottom-simulating reﬂectors (BSRs), as shown by Flood
et al. (1995) and Soh (1997, ﬁgure 11 for estimated
location of the BSR above the Western Debris Flow)
that are characteristic of the phase shift between solid
hydrate and free gas (Dickens et al., 1997). The presence
of gas hydrates has been reported in other deep-sea fans
such as the Congo Fan (Uenzelmann-Neben and Spiess,
1996). Other foot-of-the-slope slides, slumps and mega-
turbidites that have been attributed to gas-hydrate
dissociation are: the Norwegian margin (Bugge et al.,
1987), the New Jersey Margin (Dickens et al., 1997), the
Gulf of Mexico (Haq, 1993, 1995) and the Balearic
Abyssal Plain (Rothwell et al., 1998).
Secondary evidence for the possible catastrophic
release
of
gas
hydrates
are
the
extreme
negative
excursions
in
the
planktonic
foraminifera
carbon
isotope records from Sites on the Amazon Fan (Maslin
et al., 1997 and Fig. 8). Gas hydrate contains highly
depleted methane with a carbon isotopic signature of
between 40% and 100% (average is thought to be
about 60%; e.g., Kvenvolden, 1993; Dickens et al.,

Fig. 8. Planktonic foraminifera N. dutertrei carbon isotope record
from Site 932 plot against the age model developed by Haberle and
Maslin (1999) compared to the timing of the MTDs. Note that there is
a strong correlation between extreme negative excursions in the carbon
isotope record and the MTDs. This could have been due to the
catastrophic release of very negative gas-hydrate methane in to the
water column during each collapse. Note the double peak between 13
and 15 ka which may suggest the Eastern and Western Debris ﬂows
occurred at slightly different times.

1997; Dickens, 2001; Maslin and Thomas, 2003). If this
depleted carbon is released into the water column some
of it oxidizes to highly depleted carbon dioxide and is
incorporated
into
the
calcium
carbonate
tests
of
planktonic foraminifera. The planktonic foraminifera
N. dutertrei carbon isotope record from Site 932 (see
Fig. 8) plot against the age model developed by Haberle
and Maslin (1999) clearly shows major carbon isotope
excursions of up to 2% associated with both the
occurrence of Unit R MTD and Deep Eastern MTD.
These excursions are also found in the other four
planktonic foraminifera records measured for this site
and also at Site 933 (Maslin et al., 1997). The presence
of these negative excursions in the sediments coeval with
the occurrence of the MTDs strongly suggests methane
was released either just prior to or during the slope
failures.

The near-surface Eastern and Western Debris Flows,
if coeval, occurred shortly before 13 ka, during Termi-
nation 1A when sea level was rising rapidly (Fig. 7). This
suggests that they may not have been caused by gas-
hydrate release, as the increase in hydrostatic pressure
would have stabilized the hydrate deposits. It could be

speculated that a rapid rise of intermediate water
temperature could have overcome this increase in
hydrostatic pressure. This is unlikely as the transmission
of temperature changes from the sediment-ocean inter-
face to the base of the stability zone is extremely slow
due to the low thermal diffusivity of marine sediment
(Clennell et al., 1999). In addition there is no evidence
for such a rapid ‘‘threshold-like’’ rise in intermediate
water temperatures over the Amazon Fan. Hence more
likely the Eastern and Western Debris Flows may have
been caused by over-burdening of the continental slope
sediment column because of an increase and/or redis-
tribution of the Amazon River sediment discharge. An
increase in sediment discharge could have been caused
by the deglaciation of the Andes (Thompson et al.,
1995). This suggestion is supported by evidence of a
massive 10 fold increase in sedimentation rate observed
at 942 between 13.5 and 13 ka (Maslin et al., 2000). In
addition there is evidence that at the end of this high
sedimentation rate the depo-centre for the Amazon
River sediment discharge shifted. Radiocarbon evidence
from; Sites 933 (11,205755 14C years, KIA 19013), 941
(10,740780 14C years, KIA 19022), 942 (10,660750 14C
years, KIA 19025), and 944 (10,910770 14C years, KIA
19026) show a switching off of sediment supply to the
Amazon Fan at about 13 calendar ka (Fig. 7a). Hence
the Western and Eastern Debris Flow could have been
caused by either an increase in sediment deposition due
to the ﬂushing of the Amazon Basin by the deglaciation
of the Andes or the shifting the sediment depo-centre to
the continental shelf. We suggest the most likely
scenario is that the two mechanisms may have worked
in tandem so that enhanced sediment supply and
relocation
of
the
sediment
deposition
on
to
the
continental slope, causing it to be overburdened and
fail catastrophically.
What ever the cause of these two near-surface MTDs
there is evidence that they caused a secondary effect of
releasing signiﬁcant amounts of gas hydrates. First there
is evidence for signiﬁcant quantities of gas hydrates
within the Amazon Fan MTDs (e.g., Figueiredo Jr. et
al., 1996; Soh, 1997). For example Soh (1997) clearly
demonstrates from X-ray computed tomography (CT)
and pore water chemistry the presence of gas hydrate in
the Western Debris Flow sediments recovered at Site
941. Using CT, Soh (1997), showed that the gas-hydrate
content reached 10 vol% (or 17% of the pore space)
of the ﬂuidized sediment which is an equivalent to the
highest content of gas hydrate above the BSRs reported
from other gas-hydrate regions, e.g., 18% of the pore
space at the Chile Triple Junction (Bangs et al., 1993) or
8.4% of the pore space at Site 997 on Blake Outer
Ridge (Leg 164, OPD Scientiﬁc Shipboard Party, 1996).
Second the planktonic formanifera carbon isotopes
records from Sites 932 (Fig. 8) and 933 (Maslin et al.,
1997) clear show a negative peak at 13–13.5 ka which

could indicate the massive release of gas hydrates.
Interestingly, there is an earlier negative peak at
14–14.5 ka, which has led us to speculate that the
Eastern Debris Flow may not have been coeval with the
Western Debris Flow and may have occurred up to a
thousand years earlier. Unless the Eastern Debris Flow
is drilled in detail we will never know. Third the
continental shelf benthics foraminifera found in the
Western Debris Flow sediments show at least some of
the sediment within the MTD originated between 200
and 600 m water depth the critical area for gas-hydrate
instability. However, at this shallow depth the gas-
hydrate layer would have been very thin (12 m) thus
there are two possibilities which may have led to the
release of signiﬁcant amounts of gas hydrate and
methane gas trapped below it. The release of gas
hydrate and trapped methane may have occurred lower
down the continent slope as the failure continued down
to a water depth of 3500 m, 300 km away from its origin.
This is supported by the fact that the carbon isotope
excursions are recorded at sites located the Middle Fan.
The other possibility is the removal of the sediment at
the top of the continental slope produced a ‘‘champagne
cork effect’’; whereby once the sediment was removed
from the top of the BSR then the gas hydrate dissociated
down to much greater depth with the methane escaping
through the opening at the top of the continental slope
(e.g., Haq, 1998).

By using different stratigraphic techniques it is
possible to reconstruct the overall structure of the
Quaternary Amazon Fan complex, demonstrating that
it is a dynamic, complex, but highly structured feature.
A signiﬁcant portion of the Amazon Fan is made up of
MTDs, each containing up to 5000 Gt of sediment.
Biostratigraphic and sedimentary evidences show dis-
tinct subunits or blocks within the MTDs. The benthic
assemblages suggest that the source area of these block
is from the continental slope with contributions from the
shelf. The date of the formation of the MTDs correlate
with rapid, critical shifts in past sea level. We believe
that these catastrophic failure events were climatically
driven and that there are two different mechanisms
operating during the glacial (gas-hydrate release) and
the deglacial (sediment over-burdening/shifting depo-
centre) periods. The size of the events and their
associated release of gas hydrates may help to explain
the changes in atmospheric methane observed in the ice
cores (e.g., Chappellaz et al., 1990; Brook et al., 1996;
Severinghaus
et
al.,
1998;
Kennett
et
al.,
2003)
particularly if each is representative of wider continental
margin instability (Maslin et al., 2004).
